Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of Cordilleran Lithosphere: Transition From Mesozoic Shortening to Cenozoic Extension, East-Central Nevada
Award.AbstractNarration:
The geologic history of the western U. S. Cordilleran is complex and an increasing number of questions have been raised about its deep crustal architecture. The most debated question is how its geology was shaped during the transition from plate convergence and crustal shortening in the Mesozoic to divergence and extension in the Cenozoic. Across today's Basin and Range Province, this transition period is characterized by shallow-slab subduction and the shut-off of arc magmatism ~ 70-50 m.y. ago followed by one of the biggest volcanic eruption events in its history, ~ 45-20 m.y. ago, setting the stage for Miocene Basin and Range faulting. This research focuses on placing better absolute ages on events occurring during this transition period across the central part of the Basin and Range province (east-central Nevada and adjacent Utah) in order to address current controversies about this history and produce a more holistic whole-crust model for this time-span. A multidisciplinary and comprehensive approach will mesh: 1. A pioneering effort to detail the U-Pb radiometric ages, trace element and isotopic geochemistry of xenocrystic/inherited zircon populations in magmatic rocks that span the transition from shortening to extension, revealing the temperature-time history of the deep crust 2. Structural/ microstructural studies coupled with petrology, geochronology and thermochronology of key rock transects that link inferred deep levels of the crust to near surface levels in the Snake Range metamorphic core complex- a locality where deformation and cooling histories figure prominently in the debate between very thick versus thinner crust and its role in crustal flow and collapse during the transition period. 3. The time-space evolution of sedimentary basins whose history provides a robust, definitive set of constraints for evolving landforms, their relation to volcanic eruptins, and the onset of fault uplift of the deeper rocks of core complexes. This comprehensive approach will allow us to better link deep lithospheric/crustal processes such as magmatism and deformation/flow to surface processes and thus provide data to test a range of ideas and hypotheses about the lithospheric evolution of the Great Basin as it transitioned from shortening to extension.

Our geologic knowledge of the Cordillera and Rocky Mountains of the western U.S. forms the foundation for understanding its broad spectrum of natural resources, yet there are many aspects of the history of this mountain belt that are still highly debated and controversial. One of these is our conceptual understanding of fault systems formed during stretching or extension of continental crust (such as is happening today across the Basin and Range province). Despite the importance of such fault systems to the exploration of natural resources such as groundwater and hydrocarbons in continental and offshore basins, there is no consensus on how their geometries evolve through time. We also don't fully understand how surface-breaking extensional faults are linked to processes in the deep earth such as magmatic activity, heating and solid-state ductile flow of the crust, despite the importance of these questions to mineral resource exploration, hydrothermal energy sources, earthquake and volcanic hazards. Our research goals are to provide a more comprehensive data set that provides radiometric dating of events from the deep crust to surface breaking faults, volcanic eruption and sedimentary basins in order to understand the time-constrained links between deep earth processes and surface events during a time span where the Cordillera transitioned from plate tectonic convergence and shortening to divergence and extension from ~ 80 Ma to 20 Ma ago. This project will provide partial support for field and laboratory work of 3 Ph.D. and one M.S. student(s) contributing to professional training of future earth scientists. The project provides leverage to obtain funding for undergraduate research from Stanford. Compilation of geologic map data at 1:62,500 spanning the Great Basin National Park to the Kern Mountains will be made available to the general public. This map will stimulate new research and benefit teaching of geology field classes and field trips in this region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The western United States is deforming as a result of plate tectonics.  Here, human populations live next to active earthquake generating faults such as those beneath the Pacific NW (the Cascadia subduction zone) and the San Andreas transform fault in California.  East of California lies the broad Great Basin, a region of saw tooth topography where fault-bound mountain ranges and intervening valleys indicate stretching or extension in an E-W direction since at least 20 million years ago.  These regions all pose challenges in terms of our understanding of their fundamental geology, the way in which they deform, and the seismic risks posed by this deformation.

This project focused on resolving basic questions about the evolution of the Great Basin.  Many ideas or hypotheses have been proposed for the formation of this region.  One end model is that geologically older (Mesozoic) shortening of the continental crust across this region led to great crustal thicknesses such as those that underlie the modern Andes or Tibetan plateau.  Unusually thick regions of continent are weak at depth because of their composition and elevated temperatures; they can “collapse” leading to extension at the earth’s surface producing stretching-type basin and range faults.  Another model argues that the crust across the Great Basin was never over thickened and that magmatism from deep in the earth added increasing amounts of heat, weakening the continent and leading to the beginning of stretching.  

One way to address the different ideas and hypotheses above is to collect more detailed information about the geologic evolution of an area and couple that with accurate dating or isotope-based geochronology of the temporal progression of events.  We worked in the well-studied Snake Range and environs, east-central Nevada in order to answer these questions.  National Science Foundation funding helped support the field and laboratory work of three Ph.D., two MS students, four undergraduate students and involved four summer interns funded by the Brasil Science Mobility Program.  Although funding for this project was relatively minor, the project allowed us to leverage funding from Stanford University to support graduate and undergraduate students salary and research costs, leading to a greater impact in terms of our contribution to education and training as well as our scientific results.  Our students also gained important skills in analytical data collection in a variety of laboratories at Stanford and across the country and enjoyed the experience and opportunities that arose in terms of working with several different teams of scientists. 

We approached the different hypotheses above in three ways, all targeting the dating of geologic events in different parts of Great Basin continental crust:  1. A comprehensive study of the timing of onset of basin and range faulting based on the study of sedimentary basins and their stratified sections that formed as a result of this faulting at the surface of the earth.   2. A metamorphic and geochronologic study of rocks from the deeper crust to establish how deep they were buried and when they came back up to help inform questions about crustal thicknesses and time of thinning.  3.  A novel experimental interrogation of deep crust processes using the age, trace element and isotopic compositions of the mineral zircon entrained and carried upwards in the crust during Late Cretaceous and Tertiary magmatic activity.  These inherited or xenocrystic zircon crystals record a wealth of temperature-time-geochemical environment information about the source regions of the magmas. This history is  “frozen in” when they are carried to higher levels of the crust by ascending magmas that crystallize quickly. These data can also tell us when and how much the crust was thinned after Mesozoic thickening and before basin and range faulting.

Our results indicate that there is little evidence for any major surface-breaking faults prior to basin-range faulting, so there is no evidence for earlier faults that might have thinned the crust after it was presumably greatly thickened.  The metamorphic rocks from the middle or deep crust yield conflicting data. Their depth determinations don’t fit with geologic relations that show them to have been metamorphosed at shallower levels   The inherited xenocrystic zircons in magmas indicate little change in crustal thicknesses during the time-span proposed for the earlier collapse of over thickened crust.  As such, our research has helped answer some of the initial questions and our results favor end member hypothesis two, but also highlight topics of greater controversy that remain to be addressed.
